results.title: To your health
results.brief_description: Referring to the many varied opinions about alcohol, the film sets out to deal only with facts. The distribution and fate of the drug in the body is shown, and its anaesthetic properties affecting reasoning, inhibitions, memory, the special senses and muscular co-ordination described.

results.title: To Win at All Costs
results.brief_description: This is an absorbing account of the men, money and boats involved in the glittering social and sporting event that is America’s Cup yacht racing. It tells the fascinating story of the longest winning streak in sport’s history from the first race in 1851 to the highly dramatic and much publicised series of 1983 races held off Newport, Rhode Island. America, defending the coveted trophy for the 25th time, was finally beaten, giving an historic victory to the challenging “Australia II”.

results.title: To warm the world
results.brief_description: Describes the manufacture of Laconia woollen blankets as seen through the eyes of a little girl who cares for her own flock of sheep and wonders what happens to the wool after her sheep are shorn. Shows the fleece being scoured, dyed, carded and spun into yarn; weaving, milling, piece dyeing and mothproofing processes; and the drying, cutting and finishing of each blanket.

results.title: To track a shadow
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, William Canning and George Kaczender
results.brief_description: There is sometimes danger and excitement, but always a patient follow-up of clues when the R.C.M.P. hunt a killer. This film re-enacts a case from the files of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to show what is involved in modern crime detection. Some clues turn up in the laboratory; the trail of evidence leads from a lonely Alberta road to a British Columbia lumber camp and a final shootout with the murderer.

results.title: To touch a child
results.brief_description: Shows an example of an American school which opened its doors as a community centre for sport, entertainment, and educational activities. Explains how the community responded to the successful project and how it has extended to further schools in the city.

results.title: To the top
results.brief_description: This film documents the construction of C.N. Tower in Toronto Canada, which is the world’s tallest freestanding structure, built as a link for nation wide communications. The first 1500ft of the tower is concrete, followed by an observation deck and atop of this a 300ft antenna. The film explains in detail the construction techniques used to build the tower from the ground upwards assisted by the use of cranes and a helicopter. Excellent use of time-lapse photography shows the progression of construction, where 22ft of the tower is added on to every 24 hours. The challenge made by the builders to make this tower is even made harder by the freezing temperatures and snow. A 70’s score accompanies the superb photographic views with the inclusion of some nice chunky base riffs and a stummy divergence, which is reminiscent of the theme from The Love Boat.

results.title: To the rescue
results.brief_description: Air Ambulance: Saskatchewan’s air ambulance service brings quick relief to the sick or injured. Rocky Mountain Rescue: Rescue techniques used by park wardens and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to aid stranded or injured mountain climbers are demonstrated. Avalanche Experts: In the Canadian Rockies the experts often anticipate and prevent avalanches.

results.title: To the Lighthouse
results.brief_description: A film adaptation of Virginia Woolf’s most popular novel. Set in a delightful holiday home in Cornwall overlooked by a distant lighthouse which holds a haunting attraction for members of this Edwardian family. A compelling story of family relationships.

results.title: To the edge of the universe [short version]
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Douglas Cameron, Dennis Sawyer and Grant Crabtree
results.brief_description: An account of the construction, in Algonquin Park, Ontario, of a radiotelescope designed by Canada’s National Research Council. Working simultaneously with the telescope of the Dominion Radio Astrophysical Observatory at Penticton, British Columbia, it was used to measure the first arc of a quasar (quasi-stellar radio source) at the outermost fringe of our universe. The success of this probe opened up new possibilities of astronomical enquiry.
